title.narrative: ADOLESCENTS - RIGHTS TO PARTICIPATION

description.narrative: By 2021, adolescents from selected independent youth groups, networks and the National Child and Youth Council are increasingly aware of their rights to participation, the principles of digital citizenship, and have the skills and opportunities to participate, which contributes to Climate Change, Disaster Risks And Envionmental Degradation, Communication And Advocacy, Cross-Sectoral - Human Rights, Cross-Sectoral - Other Programme Areas, Cross-Sectoral Adolescent Development, Evaluation, Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Human Rights Institutions, Immunization Services As Part Of Primary Health Care, Learning, Skills, Participation And Engagement, Mental Health And Psychosocial Well-Being, Nutrition Of Adolescents And Women, Other Cross-Sectoral Programme Areas, Promotion Of Care, Mental Health And Psychosocial Well-Being And Justice, Protection From Violence, Exploitation, Abuse And Neglect, Research. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Data, Research, Evaluation And Knowledge Management, Evaluations, Research And Data, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Innovation, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2021, all adolescents, especially the disadvantaged, increasingly practice key behaviours for healthy development and participate in decision-making at all levels to accelerate the realisation of their rights.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2021, adolescents from selected independent youth groups, networks and the National Child and Youth Council are increasinglyaware of their rights to participation, the principles of digital citizenship, and have the skills and opportunities to participate

description.narrative: Meaningful participation of young people achieved with the incorporation of recommendations from 40 youth representatives from civil society into the draft13th National Economic and Social Development Plan for 2023-2027, and 61 young activists drafted a Universal Periodic Review (UPR) report on the situation of children’s participation in protests.;Online and offline participation opportunities reached 75,516 young people. A new partnership with;the National Council for Child and Youth Development (NCYD) was established for the creation of a landscape analysis on young people&39;s participation in Thailand, highlighting policies, trends and existing platforms for participation (inputs from 50 organisations received to date). | Status:On-track | As-of Date:01/02/2022
